section.p: Stories of several characters, where different characters may engage in separate activities at different locations over the same period, are produced by humans as linear discourses with no difficulty. The present article addresses this issue by engineering a computational model of the relevant task understood as that of composing a narrative discourse for the events in a chess game. The task of narrative composition is modelled as a set of operations that need to be carried out to obtain a span of narrative discourse from a set of events that inspire the narration. The model explores a set of intermediate representations required to capture the structure that is progressively imposed on the material, and connects this content planning task with a classic pipeline for natural language generation. Several strategies are explored for the linearization procedure and for the evaluation of its results. Additionally, the article considers this productive task immersed in a self-evaluation cycle where the produced discourse is validated via the construction of a possible interpretation (based exclusively on the information available in the discourse itself) and a comparison between this interpretation and the original source material.

div.p: Narrative discourse involves a linear sequence where only a single event can be told at any given point. Yet, the world that it attempts to narrate is not like that. Events may happen simultaneously in physically separated locations, and constitute more of a cloud than a linear sequence, a volume characterized by four-dimensional space time coordinates. Composing a narrative for such an input involves drawing a number of linear pathways through that volume, and then combining these linear pathways (or a selection thereof) together into a single linear discourse. This type of linear pathway is sometimes referred to as a ‘narrative thread’.

This problem rises to prominence in the case of stories of several characters, where different characters may engage in separate activities at different locations over the same period of time. Stories produced by humans deal with this issue with no difficulty, and yet, there is no computational model of how this linearization task is carried out.

Such a computational model would be useful as an extension to ongoing efforts to generate narratives from real-world data (Allen et al., 2010; Lareau et al., 2011; Bouayad-Agha et al., 2011) or to generate fictional narratives automatically (Meehan 1977; Turner 1993; Pérez y Pérez 1999; Riedl and Young, 2010).
Additionally, it may provide insights into the nature of the task that may trigger useful reflection on the part of psychologists or literary scholars.

The present article addresses this issue by engineering a computational model of the relevant task understood as that of composing a narrative discourse for the events in a chess game. This case study has been chosen because it is the simplest formulation of the problem that the author could find for which the required data were available, namely an exhaustive listing of all events that took place in the game. Chess provides a finite set of characters (pieces), a schematical representation of space (the board) and time (progressive turns), and a very restricted set of possible actions. As such, it constitutes a very simple representation of meaningful events involving a set of characters that interact over time in an elementary represented space. However, not all pieces in chess are suitable as vehicles for research on focalization. If we want to consider narratives for particular pieces that make sense from a basic cognitive point of view, we need to restrict ourselves to pieces for which a consistent pairing of restrictions on motion and perception can be established. To have pieces jumping blind into positions they have not seen would be incongruous. If they were to have a range of perception consistent with their options of motion, pieces that can move over long distances—such as bishops, rooks, or queens—would require the ability to see over the whole board—which would defeat the purpose of having different perspectives for different individuals—or a subset of the board that matched their motion—which would be radically different from human perception and would thereby introduce alienating elements into the experiment. We therefore restrict our study to focalization on pawns, which can be considered to move in a fashion compatible with a simple definition of perception in terms of visual range from a given position.

The task of composing a narrative based on a given set of events that have taken place has received comparatively less attention in terms of conceptual modelling than other aspects of narrative. Efforts have been made to capture the structure of narratives as a finished product (by the narratology research community), to come up with a set of cognitive processes implied in the tasks of writing in general or of understanding narrative in particular (by the cognitive science community), to build models of how discourse may be structured for a given plot (by the artificial intelligence community) and to construct functional architectures for generating text from conceptual data (by the natural language generation community). The task of putting together a narrative that conveys events that have already happened to more than one character is related to all these aspects. It is also the kind of basic storytelling that people carry out in their everyday lives to communicate with one another, to convince, to inform, to remember the past, to interpret the present, and to plan for the future.

Section 2 describes some prior work relevant to the goal of the article. Section 3 reviews some elementary characteristics of the task of narrative composition. Section 4 outlines the computational model proposed to address this task. Section 5 discusses the contributions of the proposed model and some of the outstanding issues, and Section 6 presents conclusions and further work.
A number of models of related tasks and elements arising from different fields of research are reviewed in this section to provide background material for the discussion.

Due to the breadth of fields under consideration, exhaustive review in any one of them is beyond the scope of the article. An attempt has been made in each case to gather here the set of elementary concepts in each field that are relevant for the understanding of the arguments in the article.

The researcher turning to narratology in search of solid theoretical grounding for his empirical models is faced with considerable difficulty. The set of existing studies on narrative is acknowledged to be controversial (Abbot, 2008). Wherever, for the purposes of this article, we have required to explain a narratological concept, we have opted to consider the restricted set of concepts that Abbot himself sets out. Two such concepts are fundamental for the discussion that follows: the distinction between story and discourse, and the concept of focalization.

According to many theorists, narrative has two components: what is told (the content of the narrative, consisting of events usually involving certain entities and taking place at given times at certain locations) and the way it is told (the form of the narrative, which involves establishing an ordering and possibly a filter on the content to be told, and providing particular means of expression for that content). These are known as the ‘story’ and the ‘discourse’, respectively.

There are alternative analyses that postulate different subdivisions. Even between theories that agree on having just two levels of analysis there seem to be many subtleties that cast doubt on whether the same thing is meant by the different words. This presents a serious obstacle for researchers from the computational field trying to address the treatment of stories in any form. An important advantage of the computational representation of narrative as a research tool is that it forces the explicit representation of the conceptual material being handled. This point will be taken up again in the discussion in Section 5, to consider whether useful insights on this issue might be drawn from the simple experiments presented in the article.

Narratologists, who specialize in the study of narrative, consider the concept of ‘focalization’ (Genette 1980) as the way in which a narrator restricts what he is telling about a particular scene to what might have been perceived by someone present in that scene. This may be one of the characters if the scene is told in the first person, or the narrator himself as if he had been present (if the story is told in the third person).

This has an interesting implication in the fact that, through focalization, narrative discourse (and thereby the structure of stories) is influenced by the perception of space: events that take place simultaneously in different locations—different cities but also different neighbouring rooms separated by a wall—usually require different narrative threads, by virtue of the fact that they cannot be perceived at the same time.

There are significant potential advantages (Herman 2014, pp. 173–4) in attempting to ground research on focalization in existing theories of how humans perceive reality as an operation of conceptualization or construal—making sense of domains of experience. A brief summary of some of the relevant ones is included below.

Two of the existing accounts of conceptualization are particularly relevant to the purposes of this article. Langacker (1987) describes how having an embodied perspective on the world influences the particular construals that language users place on events. These construals are determined by three design parameters: selection—how much of the scene perceived is included in the construal, perspective—which is central to our goal and is described below, and abstraction—how much detail of what is perceived is included. Langacker considers perspective to include a number of issues such as what to place in the foreground and what in the background, the choice of vantage point and orientation, the use of deixis and how subjective/objective to be in describing what is perceived. Along similar lines, Talmy (2000) defines how a scene is perceived in terms of a perspective point: its location within the scene, the distance to the regarded scene, whether that point is moving, and the direction of viewing from that point. These views suggests that a computational model of focalization should involve the establishment of a point of reference from which the scene is perceived and the selection of how much of the scene is to be described, and that these decisions should be defined in terms of orientation and distance. This approach has been taken as driving principle for the computational model proposed in the present article.

Flower and Hayes (1981) define a cognitive model of writing in terms of three basic processes: planning, translating these ideas into text, and reviewing the result with a view to improving it. These three processes are said to operate interactively, guided by a monitor that activates one or the other as needed. The planning process involves generating ideas, but also setting goals that can later be taken into account by all the other processes.

The translating process involves putting ideas into words, and implies dealing with the restrictions and resources presented by the language to be employed. The reviewing process involves evaluating the text produced so far and revising it in accordance to the result of the evaluation. Flower and Hayes' model is oriented toward models of communicative composition (such as writing essays or functional texts), and it has little to say about narrative in particular. Nevertheless, a computational model of narrative would be better if it can be understood in terms compatible with this cognitive model.

Although this article is concerned with modelling the process of narrative composition, it is indirectly affected by models of narrative comprehension in as much as the results of composition must be suitable for comprehension. Narrative comprehension involves progressive enrichment of the mental representation of a text beyond its surface form by adding information obtained via inference, until a situation model (representation of the fragment of the world that the story is about) is constructed (van Dijk and Kintsch, 1983).

A very relevant reference in this field is the work of Trabasso et al. (1989), who postulate comprehension as the construction of a causal network by the provision by the user of causal relations between the different events of a story. This network representation determines the overall unity and coherence of the story.

Storytelling efforts in Artificial Intelligence (AI) have focused mostly on building fictional plots from scratch, but some work has been done on structuring appropriate discourse for conveying a given plot. Some of these focus in the specific domain of cinematic visual discourse, and they include work on use of flashback and foreshadowing to produce surprise (Bae and Young, 2008) and automatic generation of camera placements over time to define a visual discourse that best fits the plot to be rendered (Jhala and Young, 2010). Others focus of modelling discourse comprehension as a criterion for the production of appropriate narrative discourse (Niehaus 2009). All of these efforts rely on a planning-based approach to narrative, with plots represented as plans. These approaches are consonant with the importance of causal relations in narrative comprehension as described above.

The general process of text generation takes place in several stages, during which the conceptual input is progressively refined by adding information that will shape the final text (Reiter and Dale, 2000). During the initial stages the concepts and messages that will appear in the final content are decided (‘content determination’) and these messages are organized into a specific order and structure (‘discourse planning’), and particular ways of describing each concept where it appears in the discourse plan are selected (‘referring expression generation’). This results in a version of the discourse plan where the contents, the structure of the discourse, and the level of detail of each concept are already fixed. Although the overall process includes a number of additional stages (aggregation, lexicalization, syntactic choice, and surface realization), these will not be relevant for the purpose of this article, which remains focused at the level of discourse, already considered as a linear sequence but still described at a conceptual level.

A number of related efforts exist to automatically derive narratives from sport games (Allen et al., 2010; Lareau et al., 2011; Bouayad-Agha et al., 2011). These efforts operate on input data in the form of statistics on a given game, and produce texts in the manner of newspaper articles covering similar games. These efforts, for instance, are heavily mediated by the set of data they start from, which arises from purpose-specific abstraction and filtering of the set of real-world events, driven by the purpose of the desired story.

Additionally, the choice of news article as target form imposes stylistic choices in terms of focalization (the stories are not focalized on specific characters) and the rhetorical structure (for instance, the need to provide a summary of the game at the beginning, then review the highlights, then comment on any relevant details). The input data considered in these cases already involve a severe operation of abstraction, in the sense that they do not constitute raw perceptions of reality but purpose-specific abstractions such as statistics on percentage of successful attempts, relative number of fouls between opposing teams, or total time that a team had control of the ball. In such cases, a large portion of the effort of converting the real-life data into story material has already been achieved by the stage of drawing statistics from the game. As such, they differ greatly from the type of input data and output text being considered in this article. For the model described here, input data would be a complete log of all events that took place in the game, and the output text would be closer to a multi-character novel describing the game, or the script of a film telling the story of the game. In the domain of chess games, specialized formats for describing a game also exist, but they are not related to the approach followed in this article.

The task of narrative composition has also been explicitly addressed by Hassan et al. (Hassan et al., 2007; Gervás 2012, 2013). Hassan et al. addressed the task of generating stories from the logs of a social simulation system. In a forerunner of the present work, Gervás focused on the task of generating a natural language rendering of a story extracted from a chess game for a given set of pieces and with focalization set at a prefixed range of perception (squares of size 3 were used). In this work, an analogy is established between the process of narrative composition and that of converting naturally occurring materials into lengths of line. This analogy is based on the similarities between the inputs (in both cases volumes of material of heterogeneous quality with no obvious unique linear presentation) and the outputs (for both a linear reorganization of selections of the same material, systematically structured to optimize certain desired qualities of the final result) of these processes. It first introduced the concept of ‘fibres’ as representation of the linear threads that configure a narrative discourse. Gervás (2012) focuses on the task of grafting together two fibres when the focalizer of ones is killed by the focalizer of the other, and the ancillary processes of natural language generation to produce text from the resulting discourse.
Gervás (2013) focused on processes of content and focalization selection by means of an evolutionary solution.
div.h2: 3 The Composition of Linear Narrative Discourse from a Non-Linear Conceptual Source
div.p: To address the task of composing a linear narrative discourse, several aspects must be considered. First, at a high level of abstraction, the purpose or goal of the composition, which will have a great influence on the decisions to be taken during the process. Second, at an intermediate level of abstraction, the nature of these linear threads that are to be constructed and how they differ from the conceptual data that we are starting from. Third, at a low level of abstraction, what is the shape of the actual data that we are working with.

At its most abstract level, the task of composing a narrative discourse must be considered in the broader context of an act of communication. There is a ‘composer’, in charge of composing a linear discourse from a conceptual source, and an ‘interpreter’, faced with the task of reconstructing a selected subset of the material in the conceptual source as an interpretation of the received narrative discourse.1 The task of the composer involves two different operations: the selection of what subset of the conceptual source to convey, and the linearization of that selection as a discourse.

The overall purpose of the communication act plays a fundamental role in the selection process, and therefore must be modelled in some way in any computational model. This purpose can range over a large set of alternatives, including but not restricted to exhaustive description of the source, describing events relevant to a particular character or set of characters, describing events leading to or arising from a particular situation, or, in more generic terms, producing a particular effect on the interpreter. Relevant issues in this respect might be knowing how much knowledge from the source is already available to the interpreter, or means of predicting impact on the interpreter. Detailed modelling of these aspects in all their complexity is beyond the scope of the article, but an effort has been made to include a minimal representation of purpose, as placeholder for more refined elaboration in further work. The composer also has the responsibility of ensuring that the discourse she produces is optimized to help the interpreter construct exactly the interpretation2 she desires to convey. Gricean principles (Grice 1975) may come into effect here. Each additional element introduced into the discourse requires an effort expended by the interpreter, so it should result in a significant contribution toward the achievement of the purpose of the discourse on the interpreter's side. This point will be used later to drive the process of discourse composition and to validate the success of a particular result.

The role of the interpreter is crucial even if the model is nominally restricted to the task of composition. According to Flower and Hayes model of the writing task, linearization would occur as part of the translation subtask (converting ideas into text), followed by a number of cycles of reviewing and improving the result. The earlier work of Gervás (2012, 2013) addresses the linearization stage but stops short of modelling this reviewing cycle. This article extends that work with a first approximation to the reviewing stage of discourse, based on an attempt at reconstructing the desired content from the discourse, and a comparison between the resulting interpretation and the selected subset of the source material. This provides some feedback on the validity of the linearization procedure carried out in the sense that no information is lost in the conversion of the content to a perspective based on particular individuals.
div.h3: 3.2 The nature of a linear thread of discourse
div.p: The establishment of linear threads over the material in the conceptual source for the discourse can be related to the identification of appropriate focalization decisions for conveying that material. Focalization, understood as the decision of which character the narration should follow, and how much of the environment around him at each point should be conveyed to the reader of the narrative, forces the perception of reality into individual fibres (one for each possible focalizer character) that are linear and sequential in nature.
For each character involved in the set of events to be conveyed, a possible focalization fibre can be drawn. These fibres must be constructed as sequences of events.

An ‘event’ is something that happens with a potential for being relevant to a story. Events occur at a specific location at a given moment of time. An event can be characterized by a set of conditions that held at the start of the event, the event itself, and a set of effects of the event. In order to have a generic representation, each event is considered to have an associated ‘event description’ that allows both a descriptive and a narrative component. The descriptive component of an event description contains predicates that describe relevant conditions at the start of the event. The narrative component of an event describes the action of the event itself, but it may also contain additional narrative predicates describing the effects of the action in terms of the relative perception of the focalizer. For instance, if someone moves from one place to another, elements at the original location may be left behind, and elements in the final location appear. These are not considered separate events but included in the description of the moving event.

A ‘fibre’ is a sequence of events that either involve or are seen by a given character. It represents a focalized perception of the world. The extent of information that is included in the events for a given fibre is defined by the range of perception that is being considered and by the presence of any obstacles to perception in the surrounding environment.

It may also be affected by the direction in which the focalizer is facing, or where he is focusing his attention. As these further refinements require advanced authorial decisions, we decided that the standard representation should include the position and orientation of the focalizer, and all the information within perceptive range, and that the decision of how much of this information to include in the final rendering should be left to a later stage of composition.

The task of ‘heckling’3 involves establishing the range of perception, tracking the set of all possible characters involved in the events to be narrated, and for each character constructing a fibre representation that includes descriptions of all the events that the character initiates, suffers, or perceives. These descriptions will appear in the fibre in chronological order.
div.h3: 3.3 Raw data from a chess game
div.p: A basic software implementation has been written that reads a description of a chess game in algebraic notation (see Table 1) and builds for it the kind of representations that are described above. The aim of this exercise is to consider the type of operations (and the relative ordering between them) required to convert the data as available for a chess game into a conceptual sequence that resembles a narrative, but which must allow reconstruction of the intended content by simple processing.
Algebraic notation for an example chess game.
Algebraic notation for an example chess game.

Each individual chess piece taking part in the game is considered a character. To model the way humans tell stories in terms of narrative threads, based on subsets of the events that can be said to be experienced by a particular character, each piece is assigned a field of perception corresponding to a M × M square around the position of the board in which it is standing. This constitutes the immediate surroundings of each piece at any given moment. The size of this region is determined by a value N that represents the ‘range of perception’ of that particular piece. For simplicity, in this initial approximation we do not consider the possible existence of obstacles that may block the perception. For a given piece with range of perception N, all squares within a distance N of the position of the piece can be perceived. This constitutes a square around the piece of size M = 2 × N + 1. All possible partitions of the chess board in M × M squares would be possible locations in our world model—depending on the positions of characters on the board.

The set of events that we would be considering is the set of all moves involved in a given game. For particular purposes, a subset of these, and even partial descriptions of those may be selected rather than the whole. Events are triggered by pieces moves. Whenever a piece moves, this constitutes an event for the piece itself, for any other piece captured during the move, and for any other piece that sees the full move, the start of the move, or the conclusion of the move.

Fibres for each of the pieces are built by collecting event descriptions for those moves that they are involved in or they see. The same event may get described differently in different fibres depending on the extent to which the corresponding focalizer is involved in it.
div.h2: 4 A Computational Model of Narrative Composition
div.p: As described in Section 3.1 above, narrative composition involves two distinct subtasks: selection of what to tell and deciding how to linearize the resulting selection. As a result of the modelling task, we have identified a number of additional subtasks: a task of heckling the perceived events into linear fibres focalized on a given individual, over which selection takes place, a task of enriching these fibres with descriptive information relative to the focalizer, a task of splicing these fibres into a single linear sequence, called a yarn, a task of filtering the information in the resulting yarn to remove redundant information, a task of contextualizing the resulting linear fragments at the point of the sequence where they are placed, and a task of validating the resulting linearization to test whether the intended content can be recovered from it without loss of information.

A computational model needs to be based on a representation of the data it is operating over. In the present case, data structures have been defined for representing an event description and a fibre as described conceptually in Section 3.2.

The data structure for representing an event description is a tuple EDt,f = (t, f, d, D, N), where t is the moment of the game at which the event starts, f is the character on which the event is focalized, d is the direction in which the focalizer is facing, D is a set of descriptive predicates for the event, and N is a set of narrative predicates for the event. For the particular domain of chess, time is represented by the ordinal number corresponding to each move, and all events have the same duration.

The data structure for representing a fibre f(i,r) is a sequence of event descriptions for focalizer i computed at range or perception r, ordered chronologically according to their assigned time. Predicates added to a fibre need to be directed to a particular event description—identified by its moment in time. They also need to be identified as either descriptive or narrative, so they can be added to the corresponding set of predicates for the event. These operations are represented as follows:
f(i,r).addD(pred,t) adds predicate pred at time t to the set of descriptive predicates for fibre for focalizer i
f(i,r).addN(pred,t) adds predicate pred at time t to the set of narrative prediates for fibre for focalizer i

This procedure creates a set of 32 fibres, one for each piece present at the start of the game. Each of the resulting fibres is created as a sequence of event descriptions all focalized on a given piece. Each event description includes predicates that describe all actions occurring within the set of squares of the board that fall inside the range of perception of that piece. Movements of other pieces are described differently depending on whether the focalizer sees the complete move, only the start of the move, or only the end of the move. When the focalizer moves, predicates are included to describe how the surrounding pieces at the start location remain behind, and how the pieces at the end location appear within his range of vision. div.p: The fibres built in this manner include all the information relative to actions perceived by the corresponding focalizer. This would correspond to the narrative content of a story. However, there is additional information that may be needed to understand what is being narrated, namely information about what pieces are present at each particular moment of the game. This information need not always be conveyed to the listener, but unless it is recovered at this stage from the representation of the game, it will be lost. A later stage must decide when to include descriptive information. Therefore, an additional procedure must be applied to extract it from the representation of the state of the game at each point, and insert it as the set of descriptive predicates associated to the event happening at that point of the game. The description associated with each event is that of the state of the visible pieces at that point at the start of the event. The resulting representation of each fibre holds the information that the corresponding focalizer would perceive. But it is still expressed in terms of coordinates for positions upon a chess board, a format that would be alien to a human perceiver in a similar position. Humans phrase their perception of space in terms of relative directions. Therefore, the absolute descriptions of positions present in the fibre must be converted into relative descriptions. Absolute descriptions occur in the fibres at this stage in two forms. One is in descriptive predicates, where the specific position of each piece being described is included as argument of the predicate. Given that we will be considering the position of the focalizer as the reference for perception, this absolute description must be converted into a description relative to the focalizer. This relative description needs to take into account the position and the orientation of the focalizer—already encoded in the event description. The relative description encodes the position of the piece being described in terms relative to the position and the orientation of the focalizer: ahead, right, left, and behind. To avoid excessively complex descriptions, only positions in the same row as the focalizer are described as being left or right of it. If the piece is facing north, pieces in a higher row are considered to be ahead and pieces in a lower row are considered to be behind. If the piece is facing south, notions of ahead and behind are inverted.

The other form in which absolute descriptions occur is in the description of movements, both real movements by a given piece and observed relative movement of static pieces as seen by moving ones. Each movement is encoded in terms of its start and its end positions. This is translated into directions relative to a global point taken as reference. To this end, we consider the chess board oriented so that the top of the board is considered the north and the bottom of the board is considered the south. Directions of this kind can then be expressed in terms of compass points, with no need to resort to positions on the board.4
div.h3: 4.2 Fibre selection and purpose of the narrative
div.p: As described above, the purpose of the narrative in a particular communication context has a great influence on its content, and thereby in the choice of fibres to use as source for building the corresponding discourse. As fibres will have redundant information, and very different coverage of the set of events to be reported, an important challenge during narrative composition will be to select the most promising set of fibres from a given inspirational set of events. Examples of particular purposes of narratives based on a chess game might be to describe as much as possible of the game, to describe what happens to a particular subset of characters, or simply to construct an entertaining story. The task of generating a narrative discourse to describe as much as possible of a chess game was the object of Gervás (2013), where exploratory solutions for the tasks of content selection are explored based on a fitness function that aims to reflect some of the qualities that humans may value on a discourse representation of a story. The task of narrating the trajectories of two particular chess pieces as they progress toward a fateful meeting was addressed in (Gervás 2012), where procedures for combining the two resulting threads and for realizing the resulting discourse as text are explored. This article focuses on the question of how to combine two or more unrelated fibres into a linear sequence that alternates between them while still allowing the interpreter to build a separate idea of what is happening to the protagonists of each fibre. To this end, we assume that a set of characters to be followed has been selected by some prior stage and concentrate on the ability for telling their stories as single integrated discourse. As explained in the introduction, the experiments will focus on the sixteen pawns rather than the full set of chess pieces involved in the game.
Splicing is the fundamental operation for handling multithreaded narratives. It involves the following operations:

li.p: identifying for each fibre a set of potential break points where the narrative flow may be interrupted to switch to a different thread;

identifying pairs of origin-target break points in different fibres such that abandoning one fibre at the origin break point and retaking the other at the target break point results in a desirable discourse.

div.p: To account for the result of this process, a further data structure is required, one that allows combinations of fragments from several fibres, while allowing sequences of events coming from a given fibre to remain grouped together and retaining for each one of these fragments information about its fibre of origin.

A ‘yarn’ would constitute the most elementary type of narrative. It should hold a sequence of fragments of fibre, possibly coming from different fibres. The event descriptions within a given fibre fragment will appear in relative chronological order, but transition to a different fibre fragment in the sequence may involve a shift in chronology. This allows for the representation of phenomena such as flashbacks or flash forwards. Transition to a different fibre fragment may also imply a change in focalization. Together with the change in chronology, this allows for the representation of alternating narration as a single linear discourse of simultaneous narrative threads.

A yarn is obtained by splicing together two (or more) separate narrative fibres that are combined into a single discourse sequence by snipping each one of them into smaller fragments and interleaving them in an appropriate order to form a single discourse that switches back and forth between them, covering their whole length.

Yarns may also be constructed by dividing a fibre into a number of fragments and recombining them in a different order. For our initial approximation, we are considering three simplifying assumptions.

First, within the integrated version of the discourse, all fragments corresponding to a given fibre must appear in relative chronological order. In terms of narratological concepts, this restricts the range of discourses to be produced to simple chronology. In further work we intend to address more refined solutions to the problem without this constraint, which will allow consideration of ‘analepsis’ (flashback) or ‘prolepsis’ (flash forward).

Second, all the events in the selected fibres must appear in the final discourse. Omission of specific fragments from the original source is indeed a fundamental operation, but we consider it to be more closely related to the task of content selection than content organization, so we leave it to be addressed jointly with the task of generating the set of fibres considered as input for the present task.
Third, the fragments into which the fibres are divided during the splicing process should be of a similar size.
The basic skeleton for an algorithm to carry out the splicing task is as follows:

li.p: start from some fibre (decision point 1)
follow the fibre until a suitable breakpoint is found (decision point 2), and take the resulting fragment as the next addition to the integrated discourse
jump to a different fibre (decision point 3)

div.p: The points in this skeleton where decisions have to be made have been marked. For each of these decision points, heuristics have to be decided.
Taking our simplifying assumptions into account, we have developed the following set of heuristics for each of them.
For decision point 1 (which fibre to start with), we consider the following heuristic: select the fibre that starts earliest (this minimizes the chronological disruption of the integrated discourse).
For decision point 2 (when to end the current fragment of fibre), we consider the following heuristic: select a point that allows a certain (random) variation in the size of the fragments.

For decision point 3 (which fibre to extract the next fragment from), we consider the following heuristic: select the fibre that has been broken the least number of times (this ensures a balanced distribution of focus over the set of fibres, so that—within the limitations imposed by the relative size of the fibres in the set—all fibres are broken up into a similar number of fragments).
The heuristics described were tested on a number of selected sets of fibres, of cardinality varying from 1 (to ensure the base case is covered), 2 and 3.

div.h3: 4.4 From yarns to spans of narrative discourse
div.p: To obtain yarns involves composition at a reasonably abstract conceptual level. This may be said to correspond to the planning process of Flower and Hayes' model, or to a content planning task in terms of the classic natural language generation pipeline model. However, the translation process of the Flower and Hayes' model (from these structural plans for the narrative to actual text) involves a further set of elementary operations that can still be considered at the conceptual level, and which are relevant for the composition procedure. Of all the possible operations, only those concerned with refining a representation of the linearized discourse at a conceptual level will be discussed here. Further details on additional operations concerned with the transcription of the conceptual representation of discourse as text are addressed in Gervás (2012).

Once a specific structure for the narrative has been decided on in terms of yarns, an important task is to establish appropriate contextualizations after each transition into a new fibre fragment. When changes occur at a certain point in the discourse to the location, the narrative time, or the focalization, these changes need to be indicated in some ways to avoid confusion and to help the interpreter in his task. In the given representation, these changes occur only at the transition between fibre fragments included in a yarn.

Whenever two fibres have been spliced together, some kind of contextualization must be added at the target breakpoint, to provide the reader with an idea of how the fibre being retaken relates to the fibre just abandoned. Expressions of the kind ‘Two days earlier, at headquarters in London, …’ play this role in narrative produced by humans, usually occurring at the beginning of new paragraphs or new chapters dealing with new focalizations.

When the structure of a yarn becomes fixed, it must be traversed in the correct sequence, adding any required contextualizations at the appropriate places. Over actual texts, these contextualizations may take different forms:

li.p: inclusion of temporal expressions or temporal discourse markers to indicate changes in chronology (usually with respect to the narrative time holding at the end of the previously narrated fragment);
inclusion of spatial expressions to indicate changes in location;
relying on combinations of the above and possibly additional discourse features (such as tense, attitude of the character, setting …) to allow the reader to infer changes in focalization.

div.p: As the last bullet point indicates, these mechanisms can be fairly complex, and a detailed analysis is beyond the scope of this article.

A narrative span corresponds to the conceptualization of the information contained in a yarn that would be transcribed into a textual representation. This includes the predicates describing state of affairs or events (usually conveyed in terms relative to the chosen focalizer), but not details such as time stamps of particular moves or absolute positions of specific pieces. At the beginning of each new focal stretch, this information is extended with additional contextual information such as the relative temporal or spatial displacement between the new focal stretch and the one that immediately precedes it in the discourse. For instance (see Table 7), when the focus of the narration, having followed the fifth black pawn for a number of moves at the top of the board, shifts to cover what the second white pawn has been doing in the meantime at the bottom of the board, the number of moves of the leap back in time and the number of squares of the board of leap to the top are annotated. Similar temporal contextualizations need to be introduced to describe gaps in the action within a given focal stretch (as in ‘Nothing happens for X moves’).

The incremental nature of discourse introduces the need for an additional operation that trims the amount of information that needs to be transmitted. As the source yarn is traversed, the content of each successive event description is checked for redundancy with the content of the previous event description, and only elements that are new are passed on to the corresponding representation as a narrative span. This relies on the assumption that the interpreter will project forward any information from one moment of the story to the next unless told differently. This helps optimize the size of the narrative span, but must be accounted for during interpretation.

The level of representation required for this stage of the composition process focuses on focalization. The yarn obtained as a result of splicing is linear, and includes all the information relevant for telling the story. However, this information still needs to be processed to extract the actual data that will shape the discourse of the story. The relevant parameters that need to be extracted are who is the focalizer at each point, how the fibres in the yarn can be reorganized into spans of narrative discourse focalized on the same character, and what changes in spatial and temporal location are involved at each change of focalization. For the present purposes, the operations of contextualization are approximated at the conceptual level by means of the construction of an additional data structure, called a ‘narrative span’. A narrative span is built of ‘focal stretches’, which correspond to stretches of discourse focalized on different characters. Focal stretches are represented by a data structure that is a sequence of ‘beats’. The data structure for representing a beat is a tuple Bt,f = (f, dist,dirt,diss,dirs, P), where f is the character on which the beat is focalized, dist is the temporal distance from the time of the previous beat, expressed in moves of the game,dirt is the temporal direction from the time of the previous beat, which can be forward or backward, diss is the spatial distance from the location of the previous beat, expressed in squares along a given direction, dirs is the spatial direction from the location of the previous beat, expressed in terms of compass points, and P is the set of predicates for the beat.

For simplicity, all data structures at this level of representation include the information on who the focalizer is, and what shifts in temporal and spatial location have been incurred in since the previous unit. div.h3: 4.5 Interpreting narrative spans to validate a linearization against a purpose
div.p: Once a narrative span has been constructed, the composer validates it against her chosen selection over the source material. This is done by building a representation of this subset as a set of fibres, reconstructing them from the linear sequence as it would be done by an interpreter. The resulting set of fibres is by definition lacking in detail, but can be compared in terms of structure and content with the originating subset of the source. This provides feedback on the validity of the linearization. Given that the present set of linearization strategies employed is based on elementary intuitions over the complete process, this check provides immediate feedback in case any of the strategies perform significantly off target.

The assignment of time moments is relative, as no absolute time values are mentioned in the discourse. Nevertheless, the relative chronological relations between the events in the reconstructed structure can be mapped onto the original source. To achieve this, the starting time of the fibres in the original content has to be discovered, and used to correlate the times actually assigned to events in the interpretation (which always start at time 1 irrespective of which relative moment in the original game the fibres started).

For this purpose, only the narrative predicates for each event are considered. Although the descriptive content of events other than the first one of a focal stretch are not recovered yet, they could be reproduced if the details of the description of the initial stage that are not affected by the narrative predicates of the event are projected as still valid descriptive predicates for the following event.

The proposed procedure for linearizing a set of fibres—representing narrative threads—for more than one character into a sequential discourse allows the systematic construction of a linear conceptual representation that conveys without loss all the narrative information (including relative timing between events) contained in the original fibres. This has been tested by developing an interpreter that can reconstruct an interpreted version of the set of input fibres that is then compared on structural terms with the originating material. This process of linearization/interpretation/comparison has been carried out for a number of possible configurations of the system, including variations in the size of snippet of fibre allowed for fragments (between 2 and 5 moves per fragment), cardinality of the set of characters considered (for 1, 2, and 3 characters), and variations in focal range (between 1, 2, and 3). In all cases tested, the interpreted set of fibres has been matched in relative structure with the original set with no loss of information.

This result relies on the fact that the interpretation process developed is designed to revert the encoding procedures applied during linearization. However, it demonstrates that the conceptual language designed to represent discourse is sufficient to encode in a linear manner the structural information of a set of parallel threads taking place simultaneously over time. To achieve this, the language has been enriched with a small set of predicate types: narrative predicates for conveying events (both absolute ones and relative ones arising from the focalized perception of the environment), descriptive predicates for conveying spatial relations in the environment, temporal predicates for describing temporal displacement between successive focal stretches of discourse, spatial predicates for describing spatial displacement between successive focal stretches of discourse, and focalization predicates that describe who the focalizer is for a particular focal stretch. Of these, all save the focalization predicates can be seen as conceptual equivalents of sentences or circumstantial complements used regularly in human language for the same purposes. The focalization predicates constitute an exception, in as much as, as described in Section 4.3, human interpreters of linear discourse have the ability to identify focalization information from contextual and linguistic data.

From the point of view of narratological theory, the model as described captures a number of important features, such as concepts of focalization and chronology, and relates them closely to the input data, the decision criteria, and the computational processes being modelled.

Most importantly, it draws attention to a number of structural elements, transformation procedures, and decision processes that are a fundamental part of narrative composition but are very rarely considered in computational terms.

These correspond to the concepts of fibre and event description, and their refinements narrative span and beat. These concepts constitute a computationally grounded view of elements of the story as they might be represented in terms of construal of a perception of the world from the point of view of a particular individual that is experiencing the story.

With respect to the theoretical references on construal presented in Section 2.1, the selection of fibres described in Section 4.2 could be matched to the design parameter that Langacker calls selection. Langacker’s perspective would be modelled by the decision to center the perception on a particular individual: in this particular case there is no distinction between foreground and background, and the vantage point and the orientation are those of the focalizer. The parameter of abstraction is in this case fixed by the chess domain: the amount of detail to include is restricted to the information available from the chess game, that is, piece names and colours and (relative) positions on the board. With respect to Talmy’s analysis in terms of a perspective point, the location within the scene is central—given the definition we are employing of range of perception—and the direction of viewing is encoded for each focalizer. Talmy’s consideration of whether the perspective point is moving is accounted for in our model in the case of moving pieces and the way in which the scene—which is actually static—is described in terms of its apparent movement with respect to the focalizer. The distance to the regarded scene, much like the distinction between foreground and background, is not very relevant given the short ranges of perception that we are considering—distances of one or two squares of the board—but might acquire more relative importance in further work once greater values are considered for the range or perception.

The set of events before processing might be considered to represent the narratological concept of ‘story’ as defined in Section 2.1. Another possibility might be that the story be the set of fibres obtained after heckling, or the subset of those fibres that get selected for inclusion in the final result. On this issue, the model presented in this article has the merit of uncovering the degree of vagueness in existing description of these concepts in narratology.

The structure proposed for yarns and narrative spans as it stands is very plain, as a result of the general aim of solving each problem with the simplest possible mechanism. However, as soon as more complex problems are addressed with the same framework, richer representation structures are bound to be needed, for instance to address the role of causal relations in the selection process. Existing narratological theories and causal models will surely be of use in extending and refining the model.

Some obvious refinements would include the possibility of focalizing a narrative thread not on a single individual but on a group of individuals that, for instance, travel together. This is a common practice in literature and should definitely be explored in computational terms. However, having more than one piece moving together is incompatible with the rules of chess and may have to be contemplated over a richer version of the underlying representation.

Following the same philosophy of first identifying the simplest mechanism that might be used to achieve the desired goal, a set of basic assumptions on the chronological features of the desired discourse has been made, ruling out instances of anachrony. Having achieved the initial goal, these assumptions can be progressively lifted in further work to explore more complex cases.

The heuristics chosen to carry out the linearization—or splicing—task represent a simple elementary mechanism that carries out the task successfully with no loss of information. More complex heuristics will have to be explored as further work. Candidate solutions for this task could explore the simplified equivalent of cliff-hanger transitions between threads, where the current thread is abandoned at a point in the story where dramatic tension is at a high point and about to be resolved, as is frequently done in films and TV series. This would require a representation of dramatic tension in the underlying model of the world.

This article addresses the task of obtaining a discourse representation from the representation of the input to a narrative composition process based on real-life events. Although a representation that captured details of causal relations between events, along the lines of the causal network model (Trabasso et al., 1989), may play a significant role in this process at a deeper level, the work described here constitutes a first approximation that tackles relatively simple structural issues dealing with time and space, not causality. Yet it is clear that further work should address the role of causality in the various decision processes identified. This may present a significant obstacle, as difficult pragmatic inferences will have to be made to interpret the causal structure underlying observed events. This task is far from trivial, as it may involve a subtask of plan recognition (Ramírez and Geffner, 2009).

Existing work on AI models of storytelling using planning approaches (Riedl and Young, 2010) may be of great assistance in that endeavour. Planning features prominently both in the storytelling literature and in Flower and Hayes' account of writing. The planning applied in most storytelling systems involves drawing causal networks that connect events to one another, in order to provide a guiding line through a story or to suggest additional events that might be added to it. Similar solutions might be applied in order to identify potentially interesting connections between events in different fibres, for instance, when events in one fibre can be causally related to events in another. Such connections could provide a very strong basis for ways of structuring the fibres into high-quality yarns.

Planning solutions may also play a role in considering refinements of the procedure in terms of anachrony as mentioned above. Modifications of temporal ordering as considered in (Bae and Young, 2008) could inform the task of dividing a fibre into a number of fragments and recombining them in a different order. Additional options of introducing temporally displaced (possibly partial) versions of a given fragment (as well as or instead of the original fragment as told in its chronological position) must be considered as further work on the model.
These possibilities should be explored in further work, once a sufficiently rich representation is found, capable of representing emotion.

The proposed stage of interpretation of the resulting linearized discourse as means of providing immediate feedback on the result of the composition process, possibly with a view to revising it would also benefit from taking into account existing work on models of discourse comprehension (Niehaus 2009), also based on planning approaches.
From a cognitive point of view, the set of operations postulated for the task of narrative composition aligns reasonably well with the processes described by Flower and Hayes.

In terms of Flower and Hayes' model, heckling the original material into fibres, fibre selection, and splicing fibres into yarns would constitute specific operations of the planning process. Contextualization would constitute an operation of the translation process, but still at the conceptual level. The model for narrative composition as described in this article constitutes a very simple initial description of the task as a one-pass attempt, but already considers that the task might be addressed in a cyclic way, involving additional processes of revision based on the evaluation obtained by means of the reconstruction of the original source as an interpretation. This could be further refined as an instantiation of the reviewing process of Flower and Hayes' model. This type of modelling should be considered to allow interaction between the various processes as controlled by a monitor.

Finally, a brief note on the use of chess games as indicative case study. Chess games present the advantage of having very clear temporal and spatial constraints, and a very basic model of the world. In that sense, chess provides a good ground for simple experiments on the operation of the model of sufficient simplicity to be describable within the size restrictions of a paper such as this. Against the suitability of the chess domain as a valid candidate for the type of research required as further work beyond this article, three aspects are identified as problematic. First, adequate representation of opportunities and threats in a chess game involves some serious representational challenges (Collins et al., 1991). Although significant progress may be made on this point, the effort invested is unlikely to lead to compelling narratives or narratives that bring insight on the task of narrative composition. Second, the specific cognitive abilities developed by chess players for addressing the challenges of the game may interfere with natural intuitions about narrative composition from the moment that a reader is familiar with the game. Third, the chronological structure of a chess game is in truth purely sequential, in contrast with the sets of events that would be considered when narrating from real-life events. This has not been considered a serious obstacle in as much as focalization breaks up the set of events into separate views corresponding to different fibres, and the numbering or moves in the game provides a good indication of relative chronology of events within any given fibre and across fibres. Yet, it also introduces unnecessary complexity when computing chronological alignment between paired break points, for instance, or in determining when jumps in time between successive event descriptions in a fibre should be flagged in the discourse. For these reasons, it is considered advisable to explore further investigation of the suitability of the model when applied to case studies in other domains that are richer in terms of their representation of time and space and that may lead to more compelling narratives with a stronger human interest. The search for alternative domains is made difficult by the need to obtain for them reliable records of all events, both relevant and irrelevant to the story that may be told. Only if this condition is satisfied can the corresponding problem be considered equivalent to the human task that we want to model.

The model presented in this article constitutes an approximation to a computational model of the task of narrative composition. The models provides a break down into subtasks that has lead to interesting insights in terms of specific knowledge-based operations that need to be carried out during composition. These operations relate reasonably well with structural features of narrative as described in literary studies, such as focalization and chronology. They can also be correlated to the set of processes described in cognitive accounts of writing. Finally, they align and integrate well with generally accepted task divisions for natural language generation. The computational implementation over a simple indicative case study based on narrating chess games has shown the feasibility of the approach in practical terms, as well as uncovering a number of elementary issues that arise from particular properties of the chosen domain. Overall, it seems fair to assume that the model might constitute a good starting point for further work both in terms of refining the model and extending the implementation to more complex case studies in other domains.

As specific research lines deserving attention, it is worth listing investigation into the role of causality in the various decisions processes, definition of procedures for trimming selected fibres to retain only the parts of them that justify their inclusion, and implementation of solutions for summarizing fragments of fibres that are uninteresting but relevant to the overall structure of the yarn. The model and the implementation should be extended to address in more detail the challenges of identifying appropriate break points at which to splice fibres together based on criteria such as dramatic tension, and of dealing with anachrony.
